entry.title: Introducing eslint-plugin-better-cap-config an ESLint plugin to improve CAP configuration
entry.content:
I've created an ESLint plugin to validate the configurations in SAP CAP Node.js applications. Yes, eslint-plugin-better-cap-config validates JSON files containing project configuration. For now, it's basically the usage of deprecated key/value entries, but it can evolve to accommodate best practices, suggestions and autofixes just like any other ESLint plugin.

It's build for modern ESLint which has introduced the concept of new languages. This offers proper support to more languages beyond JavaScript and TypeScript. eslint-plugin-better-cap-config leverages the new JSON Language rather than generic regular expressions. This makes it more powerful and flexible.

 

Demo time

Let's assume we have a simple CAP project with the following configuration in the package.json file.

"cds": {
    "requires": {
      "destinations": true,
      "html5-repo": true,
      "[production]": {
        "auth": "ias"
      },
      "messaging": {
        "kind": "enterprise-messaging"
      },
      "db": {
        "kind": "sql",
        "[production]": {
          "kind": "hana"
        }
      }
    },
    "features": {
      "cds_validate": false,
      "odata_new_adapter": false
    },
    "fiori": {
      "draft_compat": true
    }
  },

 

And the following ESLint configuration:

import cds from '@sap/cds/eslint.config.mjs';
export default [ ...cds.recommended ];

 

As we can see, it's using the ESLint config that comes with @SAP/cds. The same you get from $ cds add lint. OK, let's lint the project and see what happens:

npm run lint

ESLint shows no errors

 

Nothing. No output. No issues. No problems. Happy days, right?

Aladdin says "Not so fast Jafar!"

 

According to the CAP documentation, configuration like cds.features.cds_validate = false, cds.features.odata_new_adapter = false and cds.fiori.draft_compat = true are deprecated. For some of the deprecated config in CAP, you may get a message on the console when running the application (cds-serve, cds watch, etc). However, there are some problems with relying on those console messages:

  1. Most of the time they go unnoticed;
  2. If you don't upgrade @sap/cds and @sap/cds-dk, you won't get the new messages informing something has been deprecated;
  3. No visual cues on IDEs;
  4. Not possible to integrate to a CI/CD pipeline.

In this example, executing cds-serve doesn't return any warning or error messages on the console for the aforementioned deprecated configs.

 

ESLint Plugin Better CAP Config to the rescue!

Now, let's install and configure eslint-plugin-better-cap-config to see what changes. Using it is quite simple, it's just another ESLint plugin you need to add to your collection. Because it uses the JSON language, you need to install the @eslint/json package as well.

npm i -D @eslint/json   eslint-plugin-better-cap-config

 

Edit, the eslint.config.js file (or whatever variation you're using, eg, *.ts or *.mjs) to include eslint-plugin-better-cap-config.

import cds from "@sap/cds/eslint.config.mjs";
import { defineConfig } from "eslint/config";
import json from "@eslint/json";
import capConfig from "eslint-plugin-better-cap-config";

export default defineConfig([
  {
    files: ["**/*.js"],
    extends: [cds.recommended],
  },
  {
    files: ["**/*.json"],
    plugins: {
      json,
    },
    language: "json/json",
    extends: [capConfig.configs.recommended],
  },
]);

 

Now, we execute ESLint just like we did before, nothing else is required.

npm run lint

ESLint shows CAP config errors

 

We can see eslint-plugin-better-cap-config picked up a few deprecated configs that went unnoticed before.

Now, we fix our config:

  "cds": {
    "requires": {
      "destinations": true,
      "html5-repo": true,
      "[production]": {
        "auth": "ias"
      },
      "messaging": {
        "kind": "enterprise-messaging"
      },
      "db": {
        "kind": "sql",
        "[production]": {
          "kind": "hana"
        }
      }
    },
    "features": {
      "cds_validate": true,
      "odata_new_adapter": true
    }
  },

 

And lint the project again:

npm run lint

ESLint shows no errors

 

No issues found! Hooray!!!

This is early days for eslint-plugin-better-cap-config, there are few rules implemented so far and some others cooking.

It works with configuration in any JSON file, such as package.json and .cdsrc.json.

CAP documentation is good, but doesn't help much when looking for deprecated stuff. A central place for that would be great. Right now, I'm going through the release notes and looking for everything that's deprecated. It's a rather tedious process...

As always, the project is open-source (GitHub) and PRs are welcome ü§ñ

entry.title: Avoiding Data Loss When Loading Initial Data with CSV Files in CAP
entry.content:
Introduction

When you start learning CAP, running cds add tiny-sample generates all the necessary sample artifacts, including a CSV file inside the db/data folder. Once deployed, the data from this CSV file is loaded as initial data into SAP HANA Cloud.

This mechanism seems convenient for loading initial data into SAP HANA Cloud for productive applications, doesn‚Äôt it?
However, there‚Äôs a catch. If you change the CSV data or modify the schema, the data in SAP HANA Cloud will be reinitialized with the CSV content ‚Äî including the data entered by users! Let‚Äôs take a look at what the documentation says:

On SAP HANA, only use CSV files for configuration data that can't be changed by application users. ‚Üí See CSV data gets overridden in the SAP HANA guide for details.

This is exactly the point I want to highlight in this article. At the same time, I‚Äôve also explored some alternative approaches and validated them.

 

Case1: New Development

When developing a new CAP application, you have the following options:

  • Option A: Do not use CSV files to register initial data for tables that will be maintained by the application users.
  • Option B: If both initial data and user-generated data need to coexist, define filter conditions in the .hdbtabledata file.

Option A is the simplest, if feasible. However, in some cases ‚Äî such as for master data ‚Äî the ability to quickly load initial data from CSV files is attractive. Below, let‚Äôs look at Option B in more detail.

 

Option B: Define filter conditions in the .hdbtabledata

1. Add a column called dataCategory to the table to distinguish between different types of data. (This is just an example; you can use any column as an identifier.) 

entity Books {
  key ID    : Integer;
      title : String;
      stock : Integer;
      dataCategory: String enum {
        system = 'S';
        user = 'U';
      }
}

2. Run the command cds build --production to generate an .hdbtabledata file in the gen/db/src/data folder. Copy this file to the db/src/static/csv folder, and then add an include_filter as shown below.  This ensures that the HDI container takes ownership only of the records specified by the filter. (Note: The values must be strings, even if the column‚Äôs data type is numeric.)

{
  "format_version": 1,
  "imports": [
    {
      ...,
      "import_settings": {
        "import_columns": [
          "ID",
          "TITLE",
          "STOCK",
          "DATACATEGORY"
        ],
        "include_filter": [
          { "DATACATEGORY" : "S" }
        ]
      },
      "column_mappings": {
        "ID": "ID",
        "TITLE": "title",
        "STOCK": "stock",
        "DATACATEGORY": "dataCategory"
      }
    }
  ]
}

3. Move the CSV file into the db/src/static/csv folder as well. Don't forget to set the dataCategory to "S".

ID,title,stock,dataCategory
1,Wuthering Heights,100,S
2,Jane Eyre,500,S

4. After the initial deployment, users update some of the records and insert one new entry, resulting in the following state (as shown in the result of a GET request):

{
  "@odata.context": "$metadata#Books",
  "value": [
    { "ID": 1, "dataCategory": "S", "stock": 100, "title": "Updated" },
    { "ID": 2, "dataCategory": "S", "stock": 500, "title": "Jane Eyre" },
    { "ID": 3, "dataCategory": "U", "stock": 10, "title": "New Book" }
  ]
}

5. When schema changes or updates to the initial data are applied, records with dataCategory = "S" are overwritten, while records with dataCategory = "U" remain untouched. For example, after adding a new column newField:

{
  "@odata.context": "$metadata#Books",
  "value": [
    { "ID": 1, "dataCategory": "S", "newField": null, "stock": 100, "title": "Wuthering Heights" },
    { "ID": 2, "dataCategory": "S", "newField": null, "stock": 500, "title": "Jane Eyre" },
    { "ID": 3, "dataCategory": "U", "newField": null, "stock": 10, "title": "New Book" }
  ]
}

 

Case 2: Accidentally Mixed Data

In some cases, custom data and pre-delivered data (from a CSV file) may accidentally end up in the same table governed by an HDI Table Data artifact (.hdbtabledata) without filter conditions to separate them. 

SAP Note 2922271 outlines how to handle this situation. Below, I‚Äôll walk you through the steps.

Note: The procedure described here applies to single-tenant applications. For multitenant scenarios, please refer to the documentation, as well as @Sekar_Somasundaram's  detailed blog post. 

 

Steps at a Glance

  • Delete the CSV file.
  • Make the .hdbtabledata artifact subject to undeploy.
  • Ensure that existing data is preserved during undeploy.

 

Current State of the Data

  • The CSV file initially contains the following data:

ID,title,stock
1,Wuthering Heights,100
2,Jane Eyre,500

  • After the initial deployment, users update some of the records and insert one new entry, resulting in the following state:

{
  "@odata.context": "$metadata#Books",
  "value": [
    { "ID": 1, "stock": 100, "title": "Updated" },
    { "ID": 2, "stock": 500, "title": "Jane Eyre" },
    { "ID": 3, "stock": 10, "title": "New Book" }
  ]
}

 

Step-by-Step: Deleting the CSV File After Initial Deployment

1. Delete the CSV file.

2. Add "src/gen/**/*.hdbtabledata" to db/undeploy.json as shown below:

[
  "src/gen/**/*.hdbview",
  "src/gen/**/*.hdbindex",
  "src/gen/**/*.hdbconstraint",
  "src/gen/**/*_drafts.hdbtable",
  "src/gen/**/*.hdbcalculationview",
  "src/gen/**/*.hdbtabledata"
]

3. Copy gen/db/package.json to the db folder, and add the following parameters to the start script.

 --undeploy src/<mytable>.hdbtabledata --path-parameter src/<mytable>.hdbtabledata:skip_data_deletion=true

In my example, the package.json looks as follows:

{
  "name": "deploy",
  "dependencies": {
    "hdb": "^0",
    "@sap/hdi-deploy": "^5"
  },
  "engines": {
    "node": ">=18"
  },
  "scripts": {
    "start": "node node_modules/@sap/hdi-deploy/deploy.js --use-hdb --parameter com.sap.hana.di.table/try_fast_table_migration=true --undeploy src/gen/data/my.bookshop-Books.hdbtabledata --path-parameter src/gen/data/my.bookshop-Books.hdbtabledata:skip_data_deletion=true"
  }
}

4. Deploy the project. In the db-deployer log, you will see a message indicating that the existing data was not deleted.

[APP/TASK/deploy/0] OUT The "skip_data_deletion" make parameter is set; no data will be deleted from the target table "MY_BOOKSHOP_BOOKS"

As a result, the updated user data remains intact.

{
  "@odata.context": "$metadata#Books",
  "value": [
    { "ID": 1, "stock": 100, "title": "Updated" },
    { "ID": 2, "stock": 500, "title": "Jane Eyre" },
    { "ID": 3, "stock": 10, "title": "New Book" }
  ]
}

5. Before the next deployment, delete the db/package.json file to restore the original state. From this point on, even if the schema changes, the data will no longer be overridden.

 

Other Ways to Register Data

Besides using CSV files during deployment, you can load data through the following approaches as well:

  • Insert data via HTTP requests: Insert data after deployment using HTTP requests.
  • Upload CSV files through the Database Explorer: Upload CSV files directly from the Database Explorer.
  • For local testing: Place CSV files in the test/data folder instead of db/data (see: Location of CSV Files | capire).

* For CAP Java, configuration in application.yaml is required for loading CSV files from the test/data folder. Please find my Q&A below:

https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-q-a/cap-java-csv-data-in-the-test-data-folder-not-loaded-duirng-local-testing/qaa-p/14227290#M4927381

 

Closing

A clear strategy on how to provide initial data must be defined upfront. CSV files are convenient but must be used with caution, particularly in productive environments. Applying best practices such as separating system and user data, leveraging .hdbtabledata filters, or considering alternative loading options will help maintain data integrity and protect user input across deployments.

 

References

  • CSV Data Gets Overridden (capire) 
  • I removed sample data (.csv file) from my project. Still, the data is deployed and overwrites existing data. (capire)

entry.title: Building a CAP service with cds‚Äëmcp and Cline ‚Äî HANDS‚ÄëON SUPER BASIC GUIDE [ with screenshots ] üçå
entry.content:
Everything you‚Äôre about to read started with this brilliant SAP blog: Boost your CAP development with AI: Introducing the MCP Server for CAP. Think of it as the seed that grew into my little CAP + Cline + banana adventure. üçå

What you‚Äôll get

  • A friendly walkthrough to spin up a CAP service in VS Code
  • How to wire it to S/4HANA via a BTP Destination for local tests
  • A few real‚Äëworld bumps on Windows PATH and global installs
  • A silly ‚Äúbanana mode‚Äù at the end to prove handlers actually run üçå

Prereqs (aka ‚Äúdon‚Äôt skip me‚Äù)

  • VS Code on Windows
  • Node.js installed and on PATH
  • SAP BTP subaccount with a Destination, e.g. DEVTOBERFEST_DEST to you S4H public cloud [follow my Devtoberfest session for this]
  • Optional: Postman for poking endpoints

Step 1 ‚Äî Tools on deck

If you try to run cds init and it's not working, follow the next steps.

 

  1. CAP dev kit

npm add -g @sap/cds-dk

If global installs act shy on Windows, add this to PATH then restart VS Code:

  • C:\Users\<YourUser>\AppData\Roaming\npm

 

Step 2 ‚Äî Cline + CAP MCP server

There are a bunch of AI coding assistants out there ‚Äî GitHub Copilot, Codeium, Cursor, Tabnine ‚Äî so why bother with Cline and not Copilot or the others?

Copilot is amazing for inline coding, Cline felt like the right fit for building and testing a whole CAP service with AI in the loop.

  • Install Cline from the VS Marketplace

  • Add the CAP MCP server:
npm i -g @cap-js/mcp-server

  • VS Code settings (snip):

     

Add the MCP Server configuration to your Cline:

{
  "mcpServers": {
    "cds-mcp": { "command": "cds-mcp", "args": [], "env": {} }
  }
}

Heads‚Äëup: Agents.md wasn‚Äôt supported by Cline when I tried it; check again later.

Bonus guardrails, I told Cline:

- Always use cds‚Äëmcp to look up CDS definitions before reading *.cds files.
- Always check CAP docs via cds‚Äëmcp before proposing changes.

If you check on the bottom, you can find the model version:

Cline model picks I tried:

  • anthropic/claude-sonnet-4 ‚Äî great for agentic coding, supports images/browser/prompt caching.

  • openai/gpt-5 ‚Äî state-of-the-art for long tasks, supports images/browser, no caching.

  • x-ai/grok-code-fast-1 ‚Äî free (handy after I burned credits), supports prompt caching but no images/browser.

You can see the differences between all the models, but Grok is free. After using my 10 free prompts, I switched to Grok on my daily to continue working (but not for this blog)

Step 3 ‚Äî New CAP project

cds init

The cds init command scaffolds a new CAP project.
It creates the basic folder structure (app/, db/, srv/), adds a package.json, and sets up config files so you don‚Äôt start from scratch.

In short: it‚Äôs the ‚Äúhello world‚Äù starter for CAP ‚Äî without it, you‚Äôd have to wire everything by hand.

Step 4 ‚Äî Bring in Business Partner and scaffold

After importing the EDMX file [check my video on the Devtoberfest], let's try a prompt. We want to apply this prompt to Cline:

Extend API_BUSINESS_PARTNER.

Create service.cds and service.js.

Expose only BusinessPartner with READ and CREATE. If the name contains ‚Äúbanana‚Äù, throw an error.

Result: service.cds and service.js created. MCP caching made later calls cheaper. Nice.

For this blog, I bought 2$ of credit just for testing (I already used all the free ones). Let‚Äôs see how much it will be used.

 
 

The creation seems to be working fine, and we used 82.6k credits, which is close to $1. Let‚Äôs continue the process and create the service.cds by clicking save.

The service.js file was created correctly. We also used fewer tokens because we cached the query before sending it to the MCP server.

The file also seems fine. I would not expect anything else after this, but Cline is asking me that :

Now let me check if there's a package.json file to understand the project setup and then test the implementation. and it want to read the package.json file.

I want to be more specific in this case. I have a destination defined in my btp with already access to my S4HC and exposed the business partner scenario. I would like to test locally by using this destination and my new project. Let‚Äôs then correct and add new information with my prompt.

I would like you check the package.json and prepare the project for deploy and test locally. I have a BTP destination ready and connected with name DEVTOBERFEST_DEST

 

As a money saver, I get a little annoyed paying 3 cents to ask me to run npm install, even though I know I need to do it always.
It‚Äôs fine for testing and learning purposes lol.

And another 6 cents to check and suggested me npm start. But let‚Äôs imagine we are new in this CAP world and we follow blindly Cline and the MCP.

Step 5 ‚Äî Prep for local testing with a Destination

Have a BTP Destination named DEVTOBERFEST_DEST that points to the S/4HANA Business Partner API.

After this point, I decided to add my MTA file and the destination configuration (to connect to the system) by myself. Without using any AI tool

cds add mta;
cds add xsuaa,destination,connectivity;

Step 6 ‚Äî Build, deploy, and test


Install all the package dependencies with

npm i

I decided to build and deploy by using Cline.
Something I notice differently in my usual process is the new terminal type Cline on the right.

Everything went fine, and from my postman, I can see the call


This one was the first significant milestone. I think the most challenging part was to make VSCode (for me, who I am a Business Application Code user). Let's try something more fun.

Step 7 ‚Äî Banana mode (purely for fun)

I asked (Because why not?):

When filtering by BusinessPartnerFullName for "Sebastiano Marchesini", make every field say "banana". 

This request took the MCP multiple steps and ended with $0.89 in expenses.

entry.title: From REST to Datasphere: A CAP-based Integration Approach
entry.content:
From REST to Datasphere: A CAP-based Integration Approach

We recently wrote a blog about how we integrate data from a REST service into SAP Datasphere. For that we deployed a small service on SAP BTP, which used the OPEN SQL schema and FastAPI to write this data directly into Datasphere. That service could also be triggered via REST endpoint from SAP Datasphere directly (ZPARTNER Link, SAP Community Link).

In this blog we now choose a different setup to retrieve data and consume it into SAP Dataphere.

We Created a CAP Application on SAP BTP.

This CAP service connects to the SCIM API of SAP Datasphere, extracts users and roles, and makes the data consumable for analytics. It uses the following BTP services:

  • HDI Container
    To persist our data from the REST calls. The HDI container is deployed to the HANA Cloud instance of our Datasphere tenant, so the data can be consumed directly.
  • BTP Credential Store
    We store the credentials for the SCIM API in the BTP Credential Store and retrieve them in our CAP application securely.
  • XSUAA Authorization and Trust Management
    To secure our REST endpoints and enforce token-based access control.
  • Cloud Foundry Space
    Provides the runtime environment for deploying the CAP application.

Use Case

In our use case, we extract user information from SAP Datasphere‚Äôs own SCIM API.

We retrieve:

  • the list of users,
  • all available roles, and
  • the assignments between users and roles.

This can be helpful for reporting on the number of users in a tenant and their corresponding roles. However, the same setup can be reused to extract and process any other REST API data into SAP Datasphere.

Credential Store

We create a dedicated namespace in the Credential Store and store four secrets for the SCIM API authentication flow:

  • dsp-scim-token-url
  • dsp-scim-base-url
  • dsp-scim-client-id
  • dsp-scim-client-secret

The CAP application retrieves these secrets at runtime, ensuring no credentials are hardcoded.

XSUAA Authorization and Trust Management Service

We create a dedicated xsuaa service to get a Token URL and credentials. This service is bound to our CAP application so that every incoming request is authorized and protected.

HDI Container

We create an HDI container where the database artifacts (tables and associations) are deployed. This container is provisioned in our SAP Datasphere tenant, making the synchronized data directly available for consumption.

CAP Application

The heart of the solution is the CAP service DSPUsers.

It exposes two kinds of endpoints:

Virtual Views (live from SCIM)

  • GET /data/UsersVH ‚Üí List of users with profile info.
  • GET /data/RolesVH ‚Üí Roles with aggregated user counts.
  • GET /data/UserRolesVH ‚Üí Which users have which roles.

These views are always fresh, since they query SCIM directly.

Persistent Entities (stored in HDI)

  • GET /data/Users ‚Üí Users persisted in HANA.
  • GET /data/Roles ‚Üí Roles persisted in HANA.
  • GET /data/UserRoles ‚Üí User-to-role assignments persisted in HANA.

Actions (to sync SCIM ‚Üí HDI)

  • POST /data/SyncUsersVHToUsers ‚Üí Upserts SCIM users into the Users table.
  • POST /data/SyncRolesFromSCIM ‚Üí Stores aggregated roles in the Roles table.
  • POST /data/SyncUserRolesFromSCIM ‚Üí Refreshes both Roles and UserRoles.

This design lets you both query SCIM data live and persist snapshots into HANA for modeling in Datasphere.

The complete CAP service code is available here: Link to GitHub Repository.

SAP Datasphere

Once deployed, the HDI container is automatically integrated with our SAP Datasphere tenant. This allows:

  • Consuming the Users, Roles, and UserRoles tables directly in Datasphere,
  • Building reporting scenarios on top of user and role data,
  • Joining with other business data to enrich analytics.

To consume the entities, we need to add the HDI Container to a specific space. Also, we can now create a generic HTTP Connection. This enables to call the Endpoints for sync in a Task Chain.

Conclusion

The integration of a CAP-based service into SAP Datasphere showcases how SAP BTP services (HDI Container, Credential Store, XSUAA, Cloud Foundry) can be combined to securely retrieve and persist data from external REST APIs. By consuming SAP Datasphere‚Äôs own SCIM API, we demonstrated how to expose both live views for real-time insights and persistent tables for analytical modeling, all within a lightweight and extensible architecture.

Looking ahead, this framework can be reused for any REST API integration into SAP Datasphere, opening the door to richer reporting scenarios, advanced data modeling, and seamless orchestration with Task Chains. With this foundation, organizations gain a simple but powerful pattern for bridging external services with Datasphere while maintaining enterprise-grade security and governance.

entry.title: What‚Äôs New in SAP Build ‚Äì Q3 2025 Release Highlights
entry.content:
In Q3, we delivered several innovations across AI-powered development, ABAP project creation, modernized SAPUI5 and advanced mobile capabilities. SAP Build also reached a significant milestone with the introduction of MCP servers, allowing developers to boost productivity further with AI agents. 

Check these out in our Top 10 Release Highlights from Q3 2025! 

AI-powered development

1. Empowering developers with MCP Tools for SAP Build 

Model Context Protocol (MCP) servers are now available for the following technologies: SAP Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP), SAPUI5 and SAP Fiori. This is a huge step forward for developers working with popular IDEs and coding assistants like GitHub Copilot, Cursor and more. With these MCP servers, we‚Äôre now providing a comprehensive set of tools designed to optimize your development workflow across various SAP technologies.

Learn more in the blog post.

2. SAP HANA Cloud SQL Statement Generation in Joule

Directly in SAP Build Code, the Joule panel now offers the new command /hana-sql-gen, which enables the generation of SQL statements from natural language directly in the panel. The generated statements can be reviewed and refined in the Joule panel. Suitable SQL statements can be either copied to a SQL console or directly executed inside the Joule panel after selecting a database connection on which to run the statement.

3. Expanded AI-powered capabilities in SAP Build Work Zone

SAP Build Work Zone continues to expand its AI capabilities, bringing new built-in features to an intelligent workspace with accelerated decision-making and improved employee experiences:

  • Integration of Joule in SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition: By bringing Joule into SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition, users can now enjoy the power of Joule within their digital workplace. This eliminates the hassle of system-hopping, reduces time wasted on searching for information, and allows employees to focus on what is important. (Note: Available in early October)
  • AI-powered text and comment generation: This enables employees to quickly create, summarize, and engage with workplace content. For example, project managers can generate project status updates in minutes, ensuring their team members stay aligned.

Learn more in the blog post.

Enhanced App Development & Automation

4. Availability of SAPUI5 1.136.x-legacy-free with deprecated code removed 

SAPUI5 1.136.x-legacy-free with deprecated code removed is now available via cloud access. This means app developers can test their UI code for compliance to SAPUI5 best practices. This helps to future-proof an SAP Fiori app for future SAPUI5 versions and work on deprecated/outdated code. Developers can also provide feedback to the UI5 team.

Learn more in the blog post.

5. Create full-stack ABAP projects in SAP Build

You can now create full-stack ABAP projects or open an existing ABAP CSN as a project in SAP Build. You can also model your application using the CDS Graphical Modeler and generate ABAP development objects. By leveraging high productivity tools, this significantly accelerates time-to-market, improves collaboration and provides a standardized, compliant approach to building extensions.

Learn more in the Help Portal. ..And stay tuned! We‚Äôll share more about this topic at SAP TechEd 2025.

6. Maintenance project for released process automation projects

For process automation, we‚Äôve introduced the ability to create dedicated project versions based on an existing released version. This allows process owners to maintain parallel editable versions while keeping the latest version in place, enabling teams to focus on solving a problem without redoing everything from scratch.

Learn more in the Help Portal.

7. Outbox functionality for tasks in SAP Task Center

SAP Task Center, which provides a seamless user experience for accessing open tasks, now lets you view completed tasks in an outbox. This provides a complete view of historical data while reducing support requests and efforts around process automation instances.

New innovations for mobile

8. UI enhancements available for mobile development

The latest release of SAP Mobile Development Kit (MDK) is now available to customers, bringing with it multiple enhancements for UI creation. Developers can add a date range to their calendar controls, enable a read-only state, add required fields to forms, and much more.

Learn more in the latest blog post.

9. Support for new site experience in SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition 

Employees accessing their workspace content via SAP Mobile Start can now enjoy a new view mode with a more flexible structuring of content. They can quickly view workspace updates, company news or project dashboards, making it easier to organize and consume information in a personalized way. (Note: Available in early October)

 

10. Updates to SAP Mobile Start

As the native mobile entry point to all SAP business apps and content, SAP Mobile Start has released several new innovations that simplify employee tasks and optimize their user experience:

  • SAP Document AI integration: Allows users to upload documents and photos for automated processing. This streamlines document handling, cuts down manual work and ensures data accuracy throughout operations.
  • Enhanced push notifications with more detailed information: Load and display context-specific details directly in the push notification, providing more meaningful and informative messages.
  • Simplified onboarding via deep link: IT teams can invite users to onboard to SAP Mobile Start via an email or message and provide a deep link that the users can use to initiate a simplified onboarding process.
  • Top news on start screen: Shows the most important news in a larger format on top of the Start screen.

Learn more in the latest blog post and Help Portal.

Ready to see these in action?

Join us for the next What‚Äôs New in SAP Build Webinar on October 8th as we dive deeper into MCP servers in CAP, SAP Mobile Start innovations, and much more!

entry.title: Building SaaS Products on SAP BTP
entry.content:
Building SaaS Products on SAP BTP

Disclaimer: This article was inspired by SAP's work on modern cloud development, particularly the blog "How SAP's ABAP Cloud Partner Reference App simplifies multi-tenant side-by-side extensions," and is intended to explore these critical architectural topics further.

SAP is undergoing its largest transformation in decades‚Äîmoving from on-premise monoliths to cloud-native architecture. Products like Datasphere, Analytics Cloud, and Business Data Cloud exist only in the cloud. Yet despite this fundamental shift, most software vendors still treat SAP like it‚Äôs 2010.

Let me explain why this gap is a massive opportunity for disruption‚Äîand why mastering the SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) is much harder than the marketing suggests.

The Architectural Divide: From Monolith to Node

To understand the BTP challenge, we must first recognize the dramatic shift in enterprise architecture.

The Old World: SAP as the Center of Gravity

For decades, SAP ECC was the undisputed heart of enterprise data. Every system pointed inward. CRM, warehouse management, custom applications‚Äîeverything fed data into one central, tightly coupled system.

External Systems‚ü∂SAP ECC Monolith‚ü∂Single Source of Truth

This architecture made building SAP-integrated products deceptively straightforward:

  • Write ABAP code directly inside the SAP system.

  • Deploy via Transport Requests.

  • Access everything natively (tables, function modules, full transaction control).

I've seen incredibly sophisticated, high-performance solutions built entirely in ABAP. But notice this: many of these established ABAP vendors are slow to build cloud-native versions on BTP. This hesitation tells you something profound about the real challenges involved.

The New Reality: S/4HANA as Just Another Node

In today's distributed architecture, S/4HANA is simply one system among many. It sits alongside Salesforce, Workday, custom applications, and SAP‚Äôs own cloud products‚Äîall communicating through SAP BTP as the critical integration, extension, and application layer.

This fundamental change means you can no longer rely on deep, internal access to the core. It forces a complete overhaul of how you design and build SaaS products for the SAP ecosystem.

The BTP Reality: Why It's Harder Than It Looks

The core challenge lies in bridging the gap between the ABAP world's capabilities and the modern cloud platform‚Äôs constraints.

The ABAP Advantage (What You Lose)

When you build directly in ABAP (on-premise), you gain:

  • Direct access to all SAP objects and processes.

  • Standardized integration patterns (BAPIs, Function Modules).

  • Full transactional control and deep customization hooks.

  • 30+ years of accumulated frameworks and access methods.

The BTP Reality (What You Are Limited To)

On BTP, you are limited to officially sanctioned external access methods:

  1. APIs (REST, OData) ‚Äì when they exist and are complete.

  2. RFC Calls/Web Services ‚Äì (The "legacy" or "sidecar" approach).

  3. Custom ABAP Extensions ‚Äì (The fallback when APIs fail).

The Technical Truth: Many older, niche, or newly migrated SAP modules do not have complete API coverage for every critical workflow step. This is not a criticism of SAP; it's the reality of a massive platform in transition. Building true SaaS products on BTP requires mapping your entire solution against the SAP API Business Hub before writing any code.

The Compelling Reason to Build SaaS on BTP

Despite the integration complexity, the strategic advantages of BTP are too significant for modern vendors to ignore. BTP is the enforcement mechanism for SAP's Clean Core strategy.

Strategic AdvantageWhy it Matters
1. Leverage SAP Objects Without Core ModificationUse SAP CAP (Cloud Application Programming Model) or RAP (ABAP RESTful Application Programming Model) to extend key SAP objects (Business Partners, Sales Orders, Materials) with custom fields and logic. This ensures your solution aligns with the Clean Core approach.
2. Instant User Management and SecurityIntegrate with BTP's XSUAA service. You instantly inherit customer's users, SSO integration, saving months of development and operational overhead on identity management.
3. Customer-Specific Extensions via MultitenancyShip one product while allowing customer-specific configurations and extensions. BTP's native multitenancy handles the data and configuration isolation, dramatically lowering codebase maintenance costs compared to the old world of branched ABAP code.
4. Modern Deployment and OperationsDeploy globally without hardware investment. Scale automatically based on demand. Use modern DevOps practices and CI/CD pipelines to update all customers simultaneously‚Äîa logistical nightmare with on-premise solutions.
 

Two Strategic Approaches to BTP SaaS

Your product's architecture should align with its core purpose:

Approach 1: Extend SAP Objects

Your product becomes a natural, value-add extension of core SAP functionality, leveraging the data models customers already use and understand.

  • Best for: Solutions that enhance existing SAP processes (advanced analytics, specialized compliance requirements, industry-specific workflows).

  • Technical Focus: Heavy reliance on CAP/RAP to extend standard entities and leverage the existing SAP transactional context.

Approach 2: Build Independent with SAP Integration (Loosely Coupled)

Create your own data model using modern frameworks (CAP/Node.js, Java) and integrate with SAP only as needed for master data and transactional exchange.

  • Best for: Products that could exist standalone but gain significant value from SAP integration (planning tools, specialized industry solutions, asset management).

  • Technical Focus: Strong emphasis on the SAP Integration Suite and Event Mesh for asynchronous, reliable communication.

The Common Pitfalls I've Observed

Architectural success on BTP is often defined by avoiding these common traps:

1. The API Gap Surprise

Teams design beautiful cloud-native architecture assuming APIs exist for everything. When they discover a critical workflow is missing an API, they are forced to write custom ABAP in the S/4HANA core to create a needed OData service.

  • The Lesson: This creates a Custom ABAP Sidecar‚Äîit defeats the purpose of the BTP-native, Clean Core approach for that use case, complicating deployment and creating system-specific dependencies. Map your integration requirements against actual API availability before committing to architecture.

2. The Custom Integration Trap

A company builds its first SAP integration for Customer A, which takes six months. Customer B has different middleware, a different S/4HANA version, and unique customizations. Three years later, the company has five customers but five completely different integrations with no reusable product.

  • The Lesson: Design for product reusability from day one. Use BTP as the standard integration hub for all customers. Your product should treat the S/4HANA backend as an interchangeable service, not a monolithic dependency.

3. The Deployment Complexity

The product itself might be excellent, but if every customer implementation requires weeks of external SAP consulting to set up roles, connect services, and configure the integration, the deployment model doesn't scale economically.

  • The Lesson: Design your solution to be simple. Aim for a solution that can be deployed and configured by the customer‚Äôs existing SAP team in days, not months, using automated scripts and minimal manual steps.

My Strategic Focus

My focus is clear: to master the architecture required to build and commercialize a CAP template SaaS solution. By leveraging the best practices of the Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP) and designing for native multitenancy, I aim to provide a production-ready, clean-core blueprint that accelerates the time-to-market for modern SAP solutions. This is the strategic direction for dominating the next era of the SAP ecosystem.

entry.title: Building Custom Authentication in SAP CAP
entry.content:
This guide presenets practical example to implement custom authentication in SAP CAP (Node.js). I hav

Project Setup

Configuration Entry Point

The key to enabling custom authentication in CAP is the auth configuration in package.json. This tells the CAP runtime to use your custom middleware handler for all incoming requests, allowing you to control the identity verification process.

{
  "cds": {
    "requires": {
      "auth": {
        "impl": "auth/basic-auth.ts"
      }
    }
  }
}
 

Implementation: Core Components

1. Security Best Practices

When handling passwords, security must be the top priority. The following code demonstrates secure handling, specifically addressing the timing attack vector, which is often overlooked.

// auth/basic-auth.ts
import crypto from 'crypto';

const PASSWORD_PEPPER = process.env.PASSWORD_PEPPER || ""; 

// Timing-safe comparison prevents timing attacks
function secureCompare(a: string, b: string): boolean {
  // Ensure we compare strings of the same length
  if (a.length !== b.length) return false; 
  // crypto.timingSafeEqual is CRITICAL for password security
  return crypto.timingSafeEqual(Buffer.from(a, 'utf8'), Buffer.from(b, 'utf8'));
}

function hashPassword(password: string): string {
  if (!password) {
    throw new Error("Password cannot be empty");
  }
  // NOTE: SHA-256 is used here ONLY for simplicity in a Basic Auth example.
  // DO NOT use SHA-256 in production. Use bcrypt or argon2.
  return crypto
    .createHash('sha256')
    .update(password + PASSWORD_PEPPER)
    .digest('hex');
}

Key Security Features:

  • crypto.timingSafeEqual(): Guarantees constant-time comparison, preventing attackers from using timing measurements to guess password characters.

  • Password Pepper: An extra layer of security beyond salting.

  • Production Note: In a production system, always use bcrypt or argon2 instead of simple hash functions.

2. Database Schema

The user schema must be designed to support both local password-based authentication (for Basic Auth) and future external OAuth integrations.

// db/schema.cds
entity Users {
  key ID          : UUID;
      email       : String(255) @assert.unique;
      username    : String(100) @assert.unique;
      passwordHash: String(255);
      firstName   : String(100);
      lastName    : String(100);
      provider    : String(50);   // 'local', 'google', 'oidc'
      providerId  : String(255);  // ID from external provider (for OAuth)
      isActive    : Boolean default true;
}

3. Authentication Logic

This core function handles credential verification against the database.

const credentialsAuthentication = async ({ 
  email, 
  password 
}: { 
  email: string, 
  password: string 
}) => {
  const { Users } = cds.entities;
  try {
    // 1. Validate Input
    if (!email || !password) {
      return { success: false, message: "Email and password are required", user: null };
    }
    
    // Normalize email for consistent lookups
    const normalizedEmail = email.trim().toLowerCase();
    
    // 2. Query User
    const user = await SELECT.one
      .from(Users)
      .where({ 
         email: normalizedEmail, 
         isActive: true 
       });
       
    // 3. Security Check: Prevent User Enumeration Attack
    // Use the same error message whether the user is missing or the password is wrong.
    if (!user) {
      return { success: false, message: "Invalid credentials", user: null };
    }
    
    // 4. Secure Password Verification
    const passwordHash = hashPassword(password);
    const isPasswordValid = secureCompare(user.passwordHash, passwordHash); 
    
    if (!isPasswordValid) {
      return { success: false, message: "Invalid credentials", user: null };
    }
          
    return {
      success: true,
      message: 'Login successful',
      user: {
        id: user.ID,
        email: user.email,
        username: user.username,
        firstName: user.firstName,
        lastName: user.lastName,
      }
    };
  } catch (err) {
    cds.log('auth').error('Authentication error:', err);
    return { success: false, message: "Authentication failed", user: null };
  }
}

Key Technical Points:

  • Preventing User Enumeration: Using the generic "Invalid credentials" message.

  • Email Normalization: Ensures query consistency.

4. Express Middleware Integration

The authentication handler is implemented as Express Middleware. It parses the Basic Auth header and creates the essential CAP-compatible user object.

import { Request, Response, NextFunction } from 'express';
import cds from '@sap/cds';
// ... import credentialsAuthentication ... (from section 3)

export default async function custom_auth(
  req: Request, 
  res: Response, 
  next: NextFunction
) {
  try {
    const authHeader = req.headers.authorization;
    
    // Allow requests without Basic Auth header to proceed. 
    if (!authHeader || !authHeader.startsWith('Basic ')) {
      return next();
    }
    
    // Parse Basic Auth header
    const base64Credentials = authHeader.split(' ')[1];
    const credentials = Buffer
      .from(base64Credentials, 'base64')
      .toString('utf-8');
      
    const [email, password] = credentials.split(':', 2);
    
    if (!email?.trim() || !password) {
      res.status(401).json({ error: 'Invalid credentials format' });
      return;
    }
    
    const auth = await credentialsAuthentication({ email, password });
    const { success, user } = auth;
    
    if (success && user) {
      // CRITICAL: Create the CAP-compatible user object
      const roles = user.roles.length > 0 ? user.roles : ['authenticated'];
      
      const capUser = new cds.User({
        id: user.id,
        attr: {
          email: user.email,
          username: user.username,
          firstName: user.firstName,
          lastName: user.lastName
        }
      });
      
      // Set the user context in both CAP and Express
      cds.context.user = capUser;
      req.user = capUser;
      next();
    } else {
      res.status(401).json({ error: auth.message });
    }
  } catch (error) {
    cds.log('auth').error('Unexpected authentication error:', error);
    res.status(401).json({ error: 'Unauthorized' });
  }
}

Critical Implementation Details:

  • The user context must be set in both cds.context.user (for CAP Services) and req.user (for Express-based middleware).

5. Service-Level Authorization

With the custom handler successfully establishing the user context, you can immediately leverage CAP's built-in authorization features:

// srv/test-service.cds
service TestService @(requires: 'authenticated-user') { 
   entity Products as projection on template.Products;
}

Testing Your Implementation

Basic Authentication Test

 

Bash
 
# 1. Base64 encode your credentials (email:password)
echo -n 'john.doe@example.com:password' | base64

# 2. Test the endpoint using the encoded value in the Authorization header
curl -X GET http://localhost:4004/odata/v4/test/Products \
  -H "Authorization: Basic am9obi5kb2VAZXhhbXBsZS5jb206cGFzc3dvcmQ="

Expected: 200 OK with product data.

Unauthorized Access Test

 

Bash
 
# Test without the Authorization header
curl -X GET http://localhost:4004/odata/v4/test/Products

Expected: 401 Unauthorized.

When to Use Custom Authentication vs. Standard SAP Solutions

It's crucial to acknowledge that using XSUAA, IAS (Identity Authentication Service), or standard JWT-based authentication is the recommended and preferred approach for the vast majority of SAP CAP applications. These services offer enterprise-grade security, compliance, and integration with the SAP ecosystem.

However, the SAP CAP intentionally provides mechanisms for custom authentication. This approach is necessary when:

  • B2C Applications: Requiring fully custom registration and login user experiences.

  • Legacy System Migration: Integrating existing applications with established user databases and authentication logic.

If your use case aligns with standard enterprise authentication, you should prioritize XSUAA or IAS. Custom authentication should be a deliberate, technically driven choice.

What's Next?

This guide provides the robust foundation for custom Basic Authentication in SAP CAP. Stay tuned for the next parts of this series, where we will extend this implementation.

The journey continues!

entry.title: Creating a Hybrid CAP (Node.js) Profile with PostgreSQL on BTP from Business Application Studio
entry.content:
In this blog post, I‚Äôll walk you through how to configure a hybrid testing profile in a Node.js-based CAP project, using a PostgreSQL database hosted on BTP, and running it locally from Business Application Studio.

While setting up hybrid profiles in CAP is a common task, using them with PostgreSQL on BTP introduces a few challenges, mainly the need to connect via SSH tunneling to access the remote database from your local BAS workspace.

For more information on hybrid testing in CAP: https://cap.cloud.sap/docs/advanced/hybrid-testing 

This blog summarizes the approach I followed to solve a real-world issue raised in the SAP Community (original Q&A here). Thanks to @MioYasutake and @Willem_Pardaens for their help. Worth noting, @MioYasutake has published a great blog covering a complete Java-based CAP example, which you‚Äôll find linked in the answer of this thread.

Table of contents:

  • Prerequisites and Sample Project
  • PostgreSQL specificity on BTP
  • Creating the Hybrid Profile
  • Enable SSH
  • Secure Connection via SSH Tunnel
  • Launch the Application
  • In case of "ResourceRequest timed out" error
  • Conclusion

Prerequisites and Sample Project

In this tutorial, I‚Äôll be using a sample CAP project that was previously created and publicly available on GitHub. If you prefer to start from scratch, you can follow the official setup guide here: https://cap.cloud.sap/docs/guides/deployment/to-cf 

Just make sure to replace HANA Cloud with PostgreSQL by running the following command: 

cds add postgres --for production

Note: The cds add postgres command automatically adds a PostgreSQL resource to your mta.yaml file, using the development service plan by default. However, this plan is not available on BTP trial accounts. If you're using a trial account, simply replace development with trial in the mta.yaml as shown below:

- name: bookshop-postgres
  type: org.cloudfoundry.managed-service
  parameters:
    service: postgresql-db
    service-plan: trial

Once the project is deployed to BTP, you‚Äôll see five service instances created:

  • One instance for authorization (XSUAA)
  • One for the destination service
  • Two related to the HTML5 application repository (host and runtime)
  • And one for the PostgreSQL database

This setup represents a standard CAP deployment on Cloud Foundry with an HTML5 UI module.

Additionally, in your Cloud Foundry space, you will find two deployed applications:

  • One for the PostgreSQL database
  • And another for the backend service of your application (the -srv module)

With the basic configuration set up on BTP, we can now move on to implementing hybrid testing from Business Application Studio.

PostgreSQL specificity on BTP

- Correction added on 03/10/2025 following feedback from @antoniojmnunes 

The PostgreSQL service on SAP BTP now includes features that allow access from outside the BTP environment. This includes support for public IPs, which enable connections from external systems, as well as the instance sharing feature, which allows you to share a PostgreSQL instance across different subaccounts.

For more details, you can refer to the following blog posts:

  • PostgreSQL on SAP BTP - How-to access instances via public IPs
  • PostgreSQL on SAP BTP - Instance sharing | 'reference' service plan

If you‚Äôre interested in more official blog posts about PostgreSQL on BTP, check out this index: PostgreSQL on SAP BTP - Are you looking for official blog posts? Blog INDEX

However, in our specific use case, we are unable to make use of these features. This limitation is due to the nature of our current setup, where these options do not allow us to achieve this in practice. As a workaround, we will create an SSH tunnel between Business Application Studio and our Cloud Foundry application.

Creating the Hybrid Profile

To set up the hybrid profile, you need to modify or create the .cdsrc.json (or .cdsrv-private.json) file at the root of your CAP project. This file defines launch profiles and specific options for the cds command.

{
  "cds": {
    "requires": {
      "[hybrid]": {
        "db": {
          "kind": "postgres",
          "credentials": {
            "host": "127.0.0.1",
            "port": 63306,
            "user": "<user>",
            "password": "<password>",
            "database": "<dbname>",
            "sslcert": "-----BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----\n...\n-----END CERTIFICATE-----",
            "sslrootcert": "-----BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----\n...\n-----END CERTIFICATE-----"
          },
          "pool": {
            "acquireTimeoutMillis": 2000
          }
        }
      }
    }
  }
}

Replace the placeholders <user>, <password>, <database>, as well as the <sslcert> and <sslrootcert> fields with the credentials provided by your PostgreSQL instance hosted on BTP.

Direct access to the remote PostgreSQL database is restricted for security reasons. By creating an SSH tunnel, a local port (e.g., 63306) on your BAS environment is securely forwarded to the remote database, so connecting to 127.0.0.1:63306 effectively accesses the remote PostgreSQL instance through this tunnel.

Enable SSH

Before you can connect via SSH to your Cloud Foundry app, you need to enable this feature first by running:

cf enable-ssh bookshop-srv
cf restart bookshop-srv

If you encounter any issues, refer to the official Cloud Foundry SSH documentation: https://docs.cloudfoundry.org/devguide/deploy-apps/ssh-apps.html

Secure Connection via SSH Tunnel

Open a terminal in Business Application Studio and run the following command:

cf ssh -L 63306:<host_from_service_key>:<port_from_service_key> <application_name>

Replace <host_from_service_key> and <port_from_service_key> with the values from your PostgreSQL service key on BTP (create one if it doesn‚Äôt exist). Also replace <application_name> with the name of your Cloud Foundry application (e.g., bookshop-srv).

This command creates an SSH tunnel that forwards local port 63306 to the remote PostgreSQL database through the Cloud Foundry app.

Launch the Application

In a second terminal, run the following command to start your application using the hybrid profile:

cds watch --profile hybrid

You should see a message in the console confirming the connection to PostgreSQL on localhost, for example:

[cds] - connect to db > postgres {
  host: '127.0.0.1',
  port: 63306,
  ...
}

Your application now runs locally in Business Application Studio but using the real data from the PostgreSQL database hosted on your BTP account.

In case of "ResourceRequest timed out" error

If you see the following error: 

<message>ResourceRequest timed out</message>

It likely means that:

  • The SSH tunnel is not active
  • The SSL certificate is not loaded properly
  • The timeout is too short (hence the importance of the acquireTimeoutMillis setting)

Conclusion

Once set up, this configuration lets you develop locally from Business Application Studio while testing your application with real data from PostgreSQL. This way, you avoid redeploying the app after every change and fully leverage CAP‚Äôs hybrid testing capabilities.

entry.title: Why Clients Say No to BTP ‚Äì and How to Change Their Mind
entry.content:
Hey BTP Community! Do you know that feeling? You walk into a meeting with an innovative idea, and the client‚Äîjust hearing "SAP BTP"‚Äîimmediately rejects it. "I don't want BTP implementation!" ‚Äì they exclaim, with a look of weariness in their eyes.

Too many times, innovation, instead of solving problems, becomes... a hot potato.

Sure, there are companies boasting a full migration to BTP, but the truth is, most organizations have concerns. Concerns about the new, about the cost, about too much detachment from the stable, "on-premise" world.

But today, I'll show you how to turn that "No" into "Why didn't we do this sooner?" I'm presenting a true case that proves, in certain scenarios, BTP is not just better; it's the only sensible and secure solution.

End Customers Straight into S/4HANA

Problem Analysis: When On-Premise "Knowledge and Familiarity" Becomes the Biggest Risk.

Imagine a typical scenario: A client needs a portal where their end customers (B2C/B2B) can verify the status of their service requests (or other object/s existing in the S/4HANA).

On-premise decision: We create external user accounts directly in the S/4HANA system. We define roles just like for internal users. We have advanced control and know the system inside out. Sounds good, right?

This approach, while familiar, introduces critical risks and burdens:

  1. Security Risk: This is my biggest headache. An external user, even with the most restrictive role, works on the same system as critical business processes and your internal employees. There is a risk (or its perception) that the user will gain access to data they shouldn't. This discomfort is a real threat to your company.

  2. Performance Issues: Suddenly, your customers start working on the same system as your business processes! Increased traffic, planned jobs, mass status verifications... all of this burdens S/4HANA. Planning for increased resource consumption is required.

  3. Additional Team Workload: Every request regarding access problems, passwords, or end-customer permissions lands on your Security/Basis team's desk. This burdens them, diverting them from key maintenance and development tasks.

The "SAP Plumber" Architecture: Why Are Customers Waiting in the Dark?

This scenario was further complicated by inefficient integration processes:

  1. The Customer creates a request in an old, external Legacy System (Success - 200 - Request Created in the Lagacy System).
  2. The request is saved in the Legacy Database (Status: "Staging").
  3. The Legacy System processes requests and transfers them (via API) to S/4HANA at intervals.

And here the drama begins:

  • S/4HANA REJECTS some requests for various reasons (business rules, technical errors, missing data).
  • The client receives no feedback. They just wait. And then they wait some more.
  • Finally, the request lands on the servisk desk of... System Maintenance Experts! (Our "SAP Plumber" üîß). They painstakingly verify errors, push through messages, and waste valuable time on tasks that should be automated.

The result? Low customer satisfaction, increased pressure, and prioritization of requests that were never even processed in the first place!

 The Solution You Need: Client Portal on SAP BTP

Isolation, Visibility, Scalability ‚Äì The Three True Benefits of BTP.

Client portals are an ideal, canonical use case for SAP BTP!

How does it work, technically and business-wise?

1. Isolation and Security 

  • We deploy a new Portal Application (e.g., based on SAP CAP in Node.js or Fiori/UI5) on SAP BTP.
  • End customers log in ONLY to BTP. Their accounts, users, and traffic are completely isolated from the critical S/4HANA system
  • Key logic and statuses are handled outside the ERP, in a secure BTP environment.

 

 

2. Full Request Status Visibility

  • The BTP application integrates with the Legacy system. Since SAP CAP is Node.js, we can:

    •  

      Consume existing Legacy APIs.
    • Or, if no API exists, connect directly to the Legacy Database (using the appropriate driver).
  • From the moment a request is created, the client sees its FULL and CURRENT status, directly in the BTP application.
  • (Such app is also helpfull for technical persons)
  • S/4HANA Integration: If necessary, we use secure OData APIs from S/4HANA (read-only or controlled write access) to fetch additional, approved information (e.g., invoice number, agent name). Controlled APIs are your gateway, not an open door!

3. Unleashing Data Potential

  • A bonus that is often overlooked: If we decide to use HANA DB on BTP, we automatically gain the ability to easily consume and analyze data from the Client Portal in analytical tools such as SAP DataSphere, SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC), or Business Data Cloud (BDC).

  • Creating reports, tracking progress, measuring satisfaction, and identifying bottlenecks becomes trivially simple.

Break Client Resistance. Turn "No" into "I Need This."

A client who says "No to BTP" is actually saying:

  • "I don't want additional costs."
  • "I don't want complications."
  • "I don't understand how this will help me."

My answer:
"BTP is not an end goal; BTP is a tool that eliminates critical architectural and business risks."

When integration is so strongly tied to the SAP S/4HANA ecosystem, and the requirements are data isolation and scalability ‚Äî  SAP BTP is good choice.

Leave Kudos if You like it üôÇ

entry.title: Integrating SAP Document Information Extraction (Document AI) with SAP CAP ‚Äì Step by Step
entry.content:
Introduction :

In the SAP ecosystem, extracting meaningful data from documents such as invoices, contracts, or delivery notes‚Äîespecially in accounting, finance, and operational processes‚Äîis often a manual and time-consuming task.Since these documents are usually in PDF or scanned image formats, using traditional data processing methods to identify fields is both error-prone and unsustainable in the long run.This is where SAP Document AI comes into play.By leveraging AI-powered models, Document AI can automatically analyze documents and extract key fields such as invoice number, date, currency, supplier‚Äìcustomer information, and line items.This eliminates the need for manual data entry, making the overall process faster, more reliable, and significantly more efficient.In this blog post, I will walk you through the step-by-step process of enabling SAP Document AI on SAP BTP and integrating it with a CAP (Cloud Application Programming) project.Starting from service activation, we‚Äôll cover creating a service key, performing authentication (token retrieval), defining actions in CAP, uploading files, and storing the extracted Document AI results in a database.By the end of this guide, you‚Äôll have a fully functional CAP endpoint that can be tested via Postman.You‚Äôll learn how to send real PDF invoice files to Document AI and receive structured data in return‚Äîa foundation you can later extend with UI5 interfaces or workflow integrations.


Step 1 ‚Äî Creating the Document AI Service in SAP BTP

First, we need to enable the Document AI service in SAP BTP. To do this:

  1. Log in to your SAP BTP subaccount.
  2. Open the Service Marketplace .
  3. Find the SAP Document AI Trial service under the Artificial Intelligence category .

On the service details page, you'll see the Overview and Service Plans tabs. Click Create to create a service instance .

Select the default plan . This plan enables basic API access in a trial environment and creates the instance your CAP project needs to connect to the Document AI service.

Fill out the form below:

  1. Service: SAP Document AI Trial Version
    ‚Üí We will be using this service. Since it is a trial version, we will use the free trial quota.

  2. Plan: default
    ‚Üí Only the default plan is available in the trial environment. It is sufficient for basic use.

  3. Runtime Environment: Cloud Foundry
    ‚Üí Defines where the service will run. Cloud Foundry is often chosen for integration with CAP projects.

  4. Domain: dev
    ‚Üí Select the Cloud Foundry domain where your project is located (for example, dev, test).

Instance Name: DocAI
‚Üí You can give the service instance any name you want. This makes it easier to connect later (you can use lowercase, for example docai).

After filling in all the fields, you can click the Next button to proceed to the confirmation screens and complete the sample creation process.

Once the instance has been successfully created, the next step is to generate a Service Key for it . This key contains the authentication information needed for your CAP project to connect to the Document AI service.

  • Click the ellipsis ( ‚Ä¶ ) on the far right of your sample row .

  • Select Create Service Key from the menu .

In the dialog box:

 

  •  

    • In the Name field, enter a meaningful name such as DocAIKey .

    • You can leave the other settings at their default values.

    • Then click Create .

  • Once the Service Key is generated, click on its row to open the detail page.

After copying the JSON:

Adding Service Key details to the file To access .envthe Document AI service, we need to define credentials in our CAP project. To do this,
you can add a structure like the following to the file located in your project's root directory:.env

Correct the highlighted errors and try again.

Unsupported HTML code has been removed from your message. The HTML has been updated. Please review the message and send it when you are satisfied.

{
  "DOCAI_CLIENT_ID": "xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx",
  "DOCAI_CLIENT_SECRET": "xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx",
  "DOCAI_TOKEN_URL": "https://39c50baetrial.authentication.us10.hana.ondemand.com/oauth/token",
  "DOCAI_URL": "https://aiservices-trial-dox.cfapps.us10.hana.ondemand.com/document-information-extraction/v1"
}

In real projects , instead of manually adding these details to the file .env, service keys are automatically linked to the application. This way, the application reads credentials from environment variables ( ) and is managed more securely. Automatic linking can also be achieved during deployment via MTA or manifest files VCAP_SERVICES.

service.cdsAction Definition in File

using { app as db } from '../db/schema';

service InvoiceService {
  entity Invoices as projection on db.Invoices;
  entity InvoiceItems as projection on db.InvoiceItems;

  action analyzeAndSave(file : LargeBinary, filename : String) returns {
     documentNumber : String(60);    
    documentDate   : Date;           
    currencyCode   : String(3);      
    senderName     : String(255);    
    receiverName   : String(255);   
    netAmount      : Decimal(15,2);  
    taxName        : String(40);     
    taxRate        : Decimal(5,2);   
    taxAmount      : Decimal(15,2);  
    grossAmount    : Decimal(15,2);  

  };
}

First, we define a CAP Action to send the PDF to the Document AI service and retrieve the result . This action can be triggered from the frontend or from tools like Postman.

For example, let's define an action with the following name :analyzeAndSave

  • filefield: Retrieves PDF file content in Base64 format.

  • filenamefield: Contains the file name.

  • returnssection: Returns key invoice fields from the AI ‚Äã‚Äãservice (for example, documentNumber, documentDate, currencyCode, etc.).

This step creates the backend point that will trigger access to the Document AI service.

At this point, we need to listen for the action we defined in the backend . To do this , we add an event handler to . When the action is triggered, this handler sends the file to the Document AI service, retrieves the analysis result, and saves it to the database. The entire flow is managed within this function.analyzeAndSaveservice.cdssrv/service.js

module.exports = cds.service.impl(function () {
  this.on("analyzeAndSave", async (req) => {
    // We define the **helper functions required for the Document AI integration**.

  });
});

 

Obtaining a Token (Authentication)
Now that we've defined the service credentials in the file.env, we need to obtain an access token to send requests to the Document AI service.We'll add the following sample functionto our file:
getTokensrv/service.js

const axios = require("axios");

async function getToken() {
  const r = await axios.post(
    process.env.DOCAI_TOKEN_URL,
    new URLSearchParams({
      grant_type: "client_credentials",
      client_id: process.env.DOCAI_CLIENT_ID,
      client_secret: process.env.DOCAI_CLIENT_SECRET,
    }),
    { headers: { "Content-Type": "application/x-www-form-urlencoded" } }
  );
  return r.data.access_token;
}

This function access_tokenreturns a value from the SAP Document AI service using the information in the file. This token will be used in subsequent API calls within the Authorization header ..env

In real projects, this step is often automated through target+service binding . The CAP application reads the necessary information VCAP_SERVICESfrom environment variables to obtain the token .

In this step, we retrieve the schemas defined in Document AI and
select the appropriate one for invoices. This allows the model to determine which fields to extract (e.g., Invoice ID, Date, Currency, etc.).

const schemas = await fetchSchemas(base, token);
console.log("[DocAI] schemas count =", schemas.length);

const chosen = pickInvoiceSchema(schemas);
if (!chosen) return req.error(500, "No invoice-related schema available in DOX");
console.log("[DocAI] chosen =", chosen);

 

    • fetchSchemas: Retrieves the schema list from DOX using the access token.

    • pickInvoiceSchema: Selects the schema whose name is invoice or contains the invoice .documentType

    • If none are found, return 500 (an obvious error to the developer).

    Base64 ‚Üí Buffer conversion (prepare the file)
    The PDF file received from the client (UI5/Postman) may be in Base64 format. If it is a Data URL (for example,data:application/pdf;base64,...), remove the prefix and convert it to a true binary buffer.

let b64 = Buffer.isBuffer(file) ? null : String(file);
if (b64 && b64.startsWith("data:")) {
  const i = b64.indexOf("base64,");
  if (i > -1) b64 = b64.slice(i + "base64,".length);
}
const buffer = Buffer.isBuffer(file) ? file : Buffer.from(b64 || file, "base64");
console.log("[CHECK] filename=", filename, "buffer length=", buffer?.length);
if (!buffer?.length) return req.error(400, "Empty or invalid base64 file");

 

    • The field we will send via HTTP form-data needs to be binary ; therefore we convert the Base64 payload into a buffer .file

    • We return 400 (client error) for an empty or corrupt file .

    Create a job (submit with schemaId) We provide the selected schema and document type in , then submit the file to DocAI to start.
    options

const options = {
  clientId: "default",
  schemaId: chosen.id,
  documentType: chosen.documentType || "invoice",
};
console.log("[DocAI] submit options =", options);

const submitted = await submitJob(base, token, buffer, filename || "invoice.pdf", options);
const jobId = submitted?.id;
if (!jobId) throw new Error(`Job submit failed: ${JSON.stringify(submitted)}`);
console.log("[DocAI] jobId =", jobId);

    • schemaId: chosen.id‚Üí we use a dynamic schema id.

    • If successful, it returns a jobId; we use this ID to track the status of the job.

    • If filenamenot provided the default value is "invoice.pdf".

    Question the work and get results

    • The job runs in the background. We poll at intervals until the status is COMPLETED .

    • Once the process is complete, the extracted areas become available under .extraction

const result = await pollJob(base, token, jobId, 60000, 1500);
console.log("[DocAI] status DONE, extraction keys =", Object.keys(result?.extraction || {}));

    • pollJob(base, token, jobId, 60000, 1500)‚Üí 60 sec timeout / 1.5 sec interval .

    • Below and result.extractionyou get .headerFieldslineItems

    NOW LET'S GO TO TESTING:

    First, ...

cds watch --profile hybrid

Let's start our CAP project with the following command. (I started it this way because I chose HANA as the database .)

Sample Invoice PDF file:

 

Above is a sample PDF file we sent to the SAP Document AI service. The service automatically analyzes the invoice and extracts fields such as the invoice number, date, currency, supplier-customer information, and item information.

Testing with Postman:
Now that everything is ready on the backend, we can test the CAP action integrated with the Document AI service. To do this, use a REST client like Postman and send the following request:

  • Method: POST

    URL: http://localhost:4004/odata/v4/invoice/analyzeAndSave

    Body (JSON):

    • file name: Name of the PDF file to be uploaded

    • file: PDF file content in Base64 format

    In this answer:

    • The fields extracted by Document AI match exactly the action return types defined in service.cds.

    • These values ‚Äã‚Äãare also automatically saved to the HANA database in the background.

    In real projects, this setup isn't written manually. Instead, the Document AI service automatically connects to the CAP application via service binding . The application reads the necessary credentials directly from environment variables, and token acquisition is performed automatically in the background. This not only increases security (sensitive data like client secrets aren't visible in the code or repository) but also allows the application to run across different environments (dev, test, production) without additional configuration . During deployment, binding is provided via MTA or manifest files, and the application continues to run seamlessly with the same approach when deployed to production..envVCAP_SERVICES

 

Optional: Storing Raw Document AI JSON for Debugging:

 
 

In the Invoices entity of the schema , I defined a field called to store the original response returned by the Document AI service. This field is of type LargeString and holds all the header and line item data returned by Document AI in JSON format.RawJson

The purpose of this area:

  • Debug/Trace : Easily inspect the data returned by Document AI during development.

  • Extensibility : If I later want to add new fields or change the mapping structure, I can access the original source.

  • Data Traceability : Store raw invoice data so it can be reprocessed when necessary.

For example, when an invoice is processed, all the extraction data returned by Document AI is stored in this column. You can then open this data and clearly see which fields Document AI has recognized.

In this article, we explored how to enable SAP Document AI on SAP BTP and integrate it end-to-end with a CAP project. Each step‚Äîfrom creating the service instance and generating the service key to authenticating, defining CAP actions, and processing documents‚Äîrepresents a fundamental building block of a real-world backend automation setup.With this integration, you can now automatically process invoices or similar business documents without manual data entry. The extracted fields can be stored in your HANA database and then used for reporting, process automation, or analytics. This approach not only speeds up financial and operational workflows but also reduces human error and increases overall process reliability.In production environments, this setup is typically secured and automated through service binding, allowing applications to read credentials from environment variables without manual configuration. This ensures smooth operation across development, test, and production landscapes.As a next step, you can extend this backend integration with a SAP UI5 dashboard or management panel, enabling users to upload, view, validate, and approve invoices in real time. By doing so, you‚Äôll move from a simple technical integration to a fully functional end-to-end intelligent document processing solution.

entry.title: Implementing Custom Audit Logging in SAP CAP Applications
entry.content:
Introduction

While SAP Cloud Application Programming (CAP) provides automatic audit logging through annotations, there are scenarios where you need more granular control over what gets logged. Custom audit logging becomes essential when you want to capture specific security events, such as unauthorised access attempts or track custom business logic violations.
 
In this blog post, we'll explore how to implement custom audit logging in your CAP application to capture 403 Forbidden events when users attempt to access resources without proper authorisation.
 
This blog contains information from the SAP BTP Developer's Guide: https://github.com/SAP-samples/btp-developer-guide-cap/tree/main/documentation

Why Custom Audit Logging?

Enterprise applications often require tracking security events beyond data access. Consider these scenarios:
- Security Monitoring: Log unauthorised access attempts
- Compliance Requirements: Track specific business rule violations
- Custom Events: Capture application-specific audit trails
Custom audit logging fills these gaps by giving developers the flexibility to log any event deemed critical for security or compliance.

Setting Up Custom Audit Logging

CAP provides powerful event handlers that allow you to intercept requests and responses. Here's how to implement custom audit logging for security events:
Step 1: Create the Server Extension
Create a server.js file at the root of your CAP application and implement the custom audit logging logic:
 
const cds = require('@sap/cds')

let audit

cds.on('served', async () => {
  audit = await cds.connect.to('audit-log')
})

const audit_log_403 = (resource, ip) => {
  // we need to start our own tx because the default tx may be burnt
  audit.tx(async () => {
    await audit.log('SecurityEvent', {
      data: {
        user: cds.context.user?.id || 'unknown',
        action: `Attempt to access restricted resource "${resource}" with insufficient authority`
      },
      ip
    })
  })
}

// log for non-batch requests
cds.on('bootstrap', app => {
  app.use((req, res, next) => {
    req.on('close', () => {
      if (res.statusCode == 403) {
        const { originalUrl, ip } = req
        audit_log_403(originalUrl, ip)
      }
    })
    next()
  })
})

// log for batch subrequests
cds.on('serving', srv => {
  if (srv instanceof cds.ApplicationService) {
    srv.on('error', (err, req) => {
      if (err.code == 403) {
        const { originalUrl, ip } = req.http.req
        if (originalUrl.endsWith('/$batch')) audit_log_403(originalUrl.replace('/$batch', req.req.url), ip)
      }
    })
  }
})

module.exports = cds.server‚Äã

Step 2: Understanding the Implementation

The implementation consists of three key components:

  1. Audit Connection: Establishes a connection to the audit-log service when CAP is served
  2. Custom Audit Function: Creates security event entries with user context and resource information
  3. Event Handlers: Captures 403 errors for both regular and batch requests

The code handles two scenarios:

- Non-batch requests: Uses Express middleware to capture response status codes

- Batch requests: Leverages CAP's error handling for OData batch operations

Testing Your Custom Audit Logging

To verify your implementation works correctly:

  1. Start your CAP server with cds watch
  2. Modify user permissions: Remove the `admin` role from user `alice` in your `package.json`
  3. Send a test request: Use the following HTTP request to trigger a 403 error
GET {{server}}/odata/v4/admin/Customers
Authorization: Basic {{username}}:{{password}}
‚Äã
  • Check the console output: You should see a custom audit log entry like this:
[audit-log] - SecurityEvent: {
     data: {
       user: 'alice',
       action: 'Attempt to access restricted resource "/odata/v4/admin/Customers" with insufficient authority'
     },
     ip: '::ffff:127.0.0.1',
     uuid: '1109134c-64db-42f8-a780-2dde61cf6821',
     tenant: undefined,
     user: 'alice',
     time: 2025-05-28T04:59:43.653Z
   }
‚Äã

Conclusion

Custom audit logging in CAP applications provides the flexibility needed for comprehensive security monitoring and compliance. By leveraging CAP's event system and audit logging infrastructure, you can create robust audit trails that go beyond standard data access logging.

The implementation shown here focuses on security events, but the same principles apply to any custom audit logging requirements in your enterprise applications.
Learn more about SAP BTP Developer's Guide and More concepts: https://help.sap.com/docs/btp/btp-developers-guide/btp-developers-guide

Note: The views and opinions expressed in this post are my own.
